ARTICLE III. - ENTERPRISE ZONES 

Sec. 118-101. - Enterprise zones created pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-88-1 et seq. 
ORDINANCE NO. 98-0618  Adopted April 15, 1998 
Section 1. Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this ordinance, shall have the following meanings, except where the context indicates a different meaning is intended: 
(1)  Ad valorem tax shall mean property taxes levied for state or county operating purposes but does not include property taxes imposed by school districts or property taxes imposed for general obligation debt. 
(2)  Business enterprise means any business which is engaged primarily in manufacturing, warehousing and distribution, processing, telecommunications, tourism, and research and development industries. 
(3)  Enterprise zone means the geographic area designated in section 3 of this ordinance. 
(4)  Full-time job equivalent means a job or jobs with no predetermined end date, with a regular work week of 30 hours or more, and with the same benefits provided to similar employees. 
(5)  Low-income and moderate-income individual means a person who, at the time of hire, is: 
a.  Unemployed or unemployed for three of the six months prior to the date of hire; 
b.  Homeless; 
c.  A resident of public housing; 
d.  Receiving temporary assistance to needy families or who has received temporary assistance to needy families at any time during the 18 months previous to the date of hire; 
e.  A participant in the Job Training Partnership Act or who has participated in the Job Training Partnership Act at any time during the 18 months previous to the date of hire; 
f.  A participant in a job opportunity where basic skills are required or who has participated in such a job opportunity at any time during the 18 months previous to the date of hire; 
g.  Receiving supplemental social security income; or 
h.  Receiving food stamps. 
(6)  New job means employment for an individual created within an enterprise zone by a new or expanded qualified business or service enterprise at the time of the initial staffing of such new or expanded enterprise. 
(7)  Qualified or qualifying business means an employer that meets the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-88-1, et seq. (including O.C.G.A. § 36-88-4) and section 4(b) of this ordinance. 
(8)  Qualified or qualifying service enterprise means an entity that meets the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-88-1 et seq. (including O.C.G.A. § 36-88-4) and section 4(b) of this ordinance, and that is engaged primarily in finance, insurance, and real estate activity or activities listed under the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) Codes 60 through 67 according to the Federal Office of Management and Budget Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1987 Edition. 
Section 2. Purpose and scope. 
It has been found by the Board of Commissioners of Fulton County and the Fulton County Economic Development Division that there is a need for revitalization in certain areas of Fulton County. Revitalization will improve geographic areas within Fulton County which are suffering from disinvestment, underdevelopment, and economic decline and will encourage private businesses to reinvest and rehabilitate such areas. This ordinance should be liberally construed to accomplish these purposes. 
Section 3. Boundaries of enterprise zones. 
(a)  The Board of Commissioners of Fulton County and the Fulton County Economic Development Division have determined that the area contained in the enterprise zone delineated below satisfies at least three of the four criteria set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6. More specifically, it is determined that there is evidence of adverse economic conditions brought about by significant job dislocation within the area delineated below, there is evidence of general distress within the area other than poverty and unemployment, and there is evidence of underdevelopment within the area showing that the level of development in the nominated area is at least 20 percent lower than development activity within Fulton County as a whole. The enterprise zone created herein shall have the following geographic boundaries: 
Beginning at the intersection of the northeasterly right-of-way of Norman Berry Drive and the southeasterly right-of-way of Cleveland Avenue, said point being the True Point of Beginning; thence running northeasterly along the southerly right-of-way of Cleveland Avenue approximately 248 feet to a point; thence running easterly along the southerly right-of-way of Cleveland Avenue approximately 642 feet to a point at the intersection of the southerly right-of-way of Cleveland Avenue and the westerly right-of-way of Sylvan Road; thence running southerly along the westerly right-of-way of Sylvan Road a distance of approximately 1385 feet to a point; thence running southwesterly a distance of approximately 62 feet to a point, said point being on the City Limit line for the City of East Point; thence running westerly approximately 250 feet to a point, said point being the intersection of the City of East Point City Limit line and the northerly right-of-way of Central Avenue; thence running northwesterly along the northern right-of-way of Central Avenue a distance of approximately 448 feet to a point, said point being the intersection of the northerly right-of-way of Central Avenue and the easterly right-of-way of Norman Berry Drive; thence running northerly along the easterly right-of-way of Norman Berry Drive approximately 1337 feet to a point at the intersection of the northeasterly right-of-way of Norman Berry Drive and the southeasterly right-of-way of Cleveland Avenue, said point being the True Point of Beginning. 
(b)  Flat Shoals Crossing Enterprise Zone [Created March 17, 1999]. 
Within the area delineated below, it is determined that (1) there is evidence of adverse economic conditions brought about by significant job dislocation within the nominated area (O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6(c)), (2) there is evidence of general distress such as functionally obsolete structures, and (3) there is evidence of underdevelopment within the area showing that the level of development in the nominated area is at least 20 percent lower than development activity within Fulton County as a whole. Accordingly, there is hereby created an enterprise zone with the following geographic boundaries:

(Ord. No. 99-0408, § 1, 3-17-99; Ord. No. 01-1259, § 1, 11-21-01; Ord. No. 14-0361, 5-21-14) 
Section 4. Qualification and incentives. 
(a)  In order to encourage revitalization within the designated enterprise zone, the following exemptions from state and county ad valorem taxes are available to qualifying business and service enterprises: 
(1)  One hundred percent of the state and county ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the first five years; 
(2)  Eighty percent of the state and county ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the next two years; 
(3)  Sixty percent of the state and county ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the next (eighth) year; 
(4)  Forty percent of the state and county ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the next (ninth) year; and 
(5)  Twenty percent of the state and county ad valorem taxes shall be exempt for the last (tenth) year. 
(b)  A qualifying business or service enterprise is an enterprise which increased employment by five or more new full-time job equivalents in the enterprise zone designated in section 3 of this ordinance and which enterprise provides additional economic stimulus in such enterprise zone. The quality and quantity of such additional economic stimulus shall be determined, on a case-by-case basis, by the Fulton County Board of Commissioners. Such business or service enterprise may be new, an expansion project for an existing business or service enterprise, a reinvestment into an existing business or service enterprise, or a successor to such business or service enterprise. At no time shall this ordinance be construed to apply to a business or service enterprise's land, buildings, equipment or other property that existed at the time of enactment of this ordinance unless such business or service enterprise qualifies under section 4(d) of this ordinance. Whenever possible, ten percent of the above-described new full-time job equivalents shall be filled or staffed with low-income or moderate-income individuals. 
(c)  For a qualifying business or service enterprise located within the enterprise zone designated herein, the schedule provided for in paragraph (a) of this section shall begin in the calendar year following said enterprise's designation as a "qualifying business or service enterprise" by the Mayor and City Council of East Point and the Fulton County Board of Commissioners. Nothing contained in this ordinance shall be construed as giving any business or service enterprise or property owner a vested right to be designated as a qualifying business or service enterprise. A minimum of five new jobs must be created and maintained for a qualifying business or service enterprise to maintain eligibility for the tax exemption provided for in this ordinance. Evidence of the creation and maintenance of all new jobs within the enterprise zone shall be submitted to the Fulton County Economic Development Division by the qualifying business or service enterprise at such times as required by said division, and no less frequently than annually. 
(d)  If, on or after the effective date of this ordinance [April 15, 1998], a project within the designated enterprise zone consists of rehabilitation and improvement of an existing structure and the value of said improvement exceeds the value of the accompanying tract or parcel of land by a ratio of five to one, then the exemption schedule in paragraph (a) of this section shall also apply whether or not the rehabilitation project is carried out by a qualifying business or service enterprise. The tax exemptions pursuant to this paragraph shall commence in the year following designation of the project by the Mayor and City Council of East Point and the Fulton County Board of Commissioners as a qualifying project under this paragraph. This designation shall not be requested until completion of the rehabilitation project. 
(e)  In no event shall the value of the property tax exemptions granted within Fulton County as a whole exceed ten percent of the value of the property tax digest of Fulton County. 
Section 5. Duration. 
The area hereby designated as an enterprise zone shall remain in existence for ten years from the first day of the calendar year immediately following the effective date of this ordinance [April 15, 1998]. Ad valorem tax exemptions available to a qualified business or service enterprise in the enterprise zone herein created shall remain in effect for the full ten-year period established in section 4(a) of this ordinance, regardless of the termination of the designation of an enterprise zone. 
Section 6. Administration. 
The Fulton County Economic Development Division, together with the East Point Department of Community Services, shall administer and enforce this ordinance for the purpose of determining the applicability of the exemptions provided herein. 
Section 7. Application. 
(a)  Each enterprise desiring designation as a "qualifying business or service enterprise" under this ordinance must apply to the Fulton County Economic Development Division as well as the East Point Department of Community Services. In addition to other information requested by the Fulton County Economic Development Division, the application should be accompanied by the following items: 
(1)  A description of the business(es) conducted by the applicant at the subject location within the enterprise zone; 
(2)  Documentation reflecting the number of full-time job equivalents maintained by the applicant at the subject location within the enterprise zone as of the date of application, as compared to the number of such full-time job equivalents maintained as of the effective date of this ordinance [April 15, 1998]; 
(3)  The name and address of each employee occupying each new full-time job at the subject location within the enterprise zone, and a determination of whether each such employee was a low-income or moderate-income individual as of the date of hire for the new full-time job; 
(4)  A description and documentation of any additional economic stimulus provided within the enterprise zone by the applicant. 
(b)  For those enterprises applying for exemption under section 4(d) of this ordinance, the application to the Fulton County Economic Development Division shall be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  A description of the business(es) conducted by the applicant at the subject location within the enterprise zone; 
(2)  Documentation reflecting expenses of rehabilitation of the existing structure; 
(3)  An appraisal or appraisals reflecting the value of the structure both before and after rehabilitation; 
(4)  An appraisal or appraisals reflecting the value of the accompanying tract or parcel of land both before and after rehabilitation of the structure; and 
(5)  Photographic documentation of the structure both before and after rehabilitation. 
Section 8. Separate business locations. 
Where a business is operated at more than one location, only a location within the enterprise zone shall be eligible for the tax exemptions provided in this ordinance. 
Section 9. Record of exemption to be maintained. 
Any locations for which the tax exemptions provided in this ordinance have been granted shall maintain documentation relating to the grant of said exemptions at the address for which the exemptions were approved. Said documentation shall be exhibited to any authorized enforcement officer of Fulton County when so requested. 
Section 10. Contractual agreement. 
As a condition of receiving the tax exemptions provided for in this ordinance, a qualifying business or service enterprise shall consent to enter into a contractual agreement that outlines the tax exemptions offered to such business or service enterprise and that further provides guidelines for the recapture, revocation or reimbursement of taxes should the terms of the contractual agreement, this ordinance or the Georgia Enterprise Zone Employment Act of 1997 be violated by the business or service enterprise. 
Chapter 122 - COURTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Justice system coordinating committee, § 102-631 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 146. 
Local Constitutional Amendments and Local Acts reference— Courts, ch. 10. 

Sec. 122-1. - Use of annex buildings for judicial operations and court services. 
(a)  The county annex building located in South Fulton County on Stonewall Tell Road and the county annex building in North Fulton County on Roswell Road are hereby declared county sites and designated for all uses and purposes otherwise allowable by law at such annex buildings by the superior court, state court, probate court and juvenile courts, provided that said courts maintain their court and their central depository for the keeping of all records at their present courthouses in the City of Atlanta, Fulton County, Georgia. 
(b)  To the extent allowed by the law and Constitution of the State of Georgia, the judges of the above-named courts of Fulton County are authorized to sit and hold court at the annex buildings on all matters within their jurisdiction. 
(c)  The chief judge of the state court is respectfully requested to implement the act of 1980 providing for the appointment of magistrates by designating and directing the newly appointed magistrates to maintain offices and conduct hearings and trials at the annex buildings. 
(Code 1983, § 25-1-1) 
Sec. 122-2. - Security. 
The rules and regulations regarding security for the Fulton County Superior Court building promulgated by the judges of the supreme court, effective June 11, 1984, are hereby incorporated by reference as a part of this chapter. Further, the director of public buildings is directed to comply with those same rules and regulations. 
(Code 1983, § 25-1-5) 
Sec. 122-3. - Supervision of law library. 
The law library shall be under the supervision of the court administrator of the superior court. 
(Code 1983, § 25-3-1) 
State Law reference— County law libraries, O.C.G.A. § 36-15-1 et seq. 
Sec. 122-4. - Display and maintenance of flags in courtrooms. 
The county manager and director of public buildings shall have the American flag properly displayed in each courtroom in the superior, criminal, and civil courts. The officers shall be responsible for keeping of all of the American flags in a clean condition. 
(Code 1983, § 23-3-36) 
Sec. 122-5. - Waiver of costs to City of Atlanta. 
Fulton County shall waive all court costs, save stenographic fees, in all litigation in the several courts of Fulton County to which the City of Atlanta is a party and in which the City of Atlanta is charged with the payment of costs. The Clerk of the Superior Court of Fulton County and the Sheriff of Fulton County are hereby authorized to recognize this waiver of costs and to make such entries on their official records as may be required to relieve the City of Atlanta of court costs under the authority of this section. 
(Code 1983, § 25-1-3) 
Sec. 122-6. - Designation of satellite courthouse on Fulton Industrial Boulevard. 
(a)  The building located at 5500-B Fulton Industrial Boulevard, Atlanta, Georgia 30336 is hereby declared a satellite courthouse pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 15-6-18(c)(1) and designated for all judicial operations, court services, uses and purposes otherwise allowable by law by superior, state and magistrate courts. 
(b)  To the extent allowed by the law and Constitution of the State of Georgia, the judges of the Superior, State and Magistrate Courts of Fulton County are authorized to sit and hold sessions of court and to conduct all other superior, state and magistrate court business at this satellite courthouse location. 
(14-0932, 11-5-14; 15-0516, 6-17-15) 
Chapter 126 - CULTURAL AFFAIRS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - ART[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Arts and science program authorized, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(10). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 126-31—126-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ARTS COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Boards, commissions, etc., § 102-601 et seq. 

Sec. 126-46. - Creation; organization; members. 
The Board of Commissioners of Fulton County does hereby create a council of citizens known as the Fulton County Arts Council, to be structured and to function as follows: 
(1)  The arts council shall be composed of 15 residents of the county. 
(2)  Initially each member of the board of commissioners shall appoint two persons to serve on the council, one person to serve for a one-year term and one person to serve for a two-year term. Thereafter, each year each member of the board of commissioners shall appoint one member for a two-year term. 
(3)  The chairman of the arts council shall be appointed to a two-year term by a majority vote of the board of commissioners. 
(4)  The council shall elect a vice-chairman and a secretary from its membership. 
(Code 1983, § 22-6-1(a)) 
Sec. 126-47. - Annual art plan; contents; priorities of art council. 
(a)  More specifically, the board of commissioners will request the arts council to submit an art plan for each calendar year which will include: 
(1)  A definition of needs; 
(2)  A resolution of these needs; and 
(3)  A request for support of programs by specific contracts which would include: 
a.  Contracts with larger organizations for annual programs; and 
b.  Contracts with smaller organizations for semiannual programs. 
(b)  The arts council, as here established, shall give priority to programs which will introduce the arts to new audiences, and will ensure that the enjoyment of the arts is available to all citizens of the county and most especially children, the elderly, the handicapped, and those citizens who, because of economic or other circumstances, have not had ready and regular access to the arts. 
(Code 1983, § 22-6-1(b)(3)) 
Secs. 126-48—126-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ART IN PUBLIC PLACES PROGRAM 

Sec. 126-66. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
Art or works of art or art works means the objects resulting from the application of skill and taste to production of tangible objects, designs, and/or environments according to aesthetic principles including, but not limited to, paintings, sculptures, engravings, carvings, frescoes, mobiles, murals, collages, mosaics, statues, bas-reliefs, tapestries, photographs, and drawings. 
Construction costs means the total costs of acquiring and constructing a capital project, including, without limitation, legal, architectural, engineering, and other professional fees, site work, contingency allowances, and change orders. 
FCAC means the Fulton County Arts Council, or such other body as may be created by the board of commissioners from time to time for the purpose of advising or managing the support, presentation and maintenance of the county's art and/or art programs or for the purpose of performing the duties reserved to the FCAC hereunder. 
Public art committee means the public art committee of the FCAC or such other similar committee of the FCAC as the FCAC or the Fulton County Commission may establish from time to time for purposes including performance of the duties reserved to the public art committee hereunder. 
Public places means buildings, real property, or other facilities owned or operated by Fulton County. 
Renovation means any construction or cosmetic change costing over $100,000.00 in manhours or supplies. This excludes regular maintenance of facilities such as painting, gutters, etc. 
(93-RC-112, § 4, 4-7-93) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 101-2. 
Sec. 126-67. - Creation. 
There is hereby created a Fulton County Art in Public Places Program. 
(93-RC-112, § 1, 4-7-93) 
Sec. 126-68. - Execution of contracts; conditions. 
No contract shall be executed by Fulton County for the construction, acquisition, or renovation of any governmental building or other capital facility owned or to be acquired by the county (capital project) unless at least one percent of the construction costs for such capital project are used for the presentation, commissioning, purchase, conservation, transportation, installation, protection, and maintenance of art in public places, which amounts are referred to as art funds. 
(93-RC-112, § 2, 4-7-93) 
Cross reference— Purchases and contracts, § 102-351 et seq. 
Sec. 126-69. - Use of art funds. 
The art funds portion of any contract referred to in section 126-68 shall be disbursed for use in connection with such capital project as directed by the FCAC through its public art committee for the purposes of providing art in public places. Such art funds shall be used to provide works of art in, on, or near such new or renovated capital project, as appropriate, and in, on, or near existing public places owned, funded, or operated by Fulton County. In addition, such art funds may be used for: 
(1)  The transportation, installation, protection, conservation, and maintenance of art in public places including, without limitation, costs of program administration, staff, insurance, security, conservation, restoration or other repair, framing, and maintenance of any works of art owned by or in the possession of the county; 
(2)  Payment of any and all expenses associated with the borrowing of art works from other persons, entities, or institutions for exhibit in public places; 
(3)  Payment of any and all expenses associated with the commissioning of art for public places including, without limitation, the preparation and dissemination of requests for proposals; 
(4)  Payment of any and all expenses associated with the presenting, commissioning, and/or judging of exhibitions of art works to be presented in public places by the county, the FCAC or others; and 
(5)  Payment of curatorial expenses, consulting fees and other professional fees or expenses incurred in the implementation of this art in public places division. 
(93-RC-112, § 3, 4-7-93) 
Sec. 126-70. - Capital project contracts; review and certification required. 
No contract for a capital project shall be presented for approval by Fulton County unless it has been reviewed by the FCAC and contains a certification that the provisions of this division have been complied with. 
(93-RC-112, § 5, 4-7-93) 
Chapter 130 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 130-1—130-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.; local organizations for emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27. 

Sec. 130-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Emergency management means the preparation for and the execution of all emergency functions, other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible, to mitigate, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin, caused by enemy attack, sabotage, civil disturbance, major accident, fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, oil spill, or other water contaminations requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot or other hostile action, or other causes. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, warning services, communications, defense from radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-2) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 101-2. 
Sec. 130-32. - Policy and purpose of article. 
Because of the existing and increasing possibility of the occurrence of emergencies or disasters, resulting from manmade or natural causes, or enemy attack, and in order to ensure that the preparations of Fulton County will be adequate to deal with such emergencies or disasters, and generally to provide for the common defense and to protect the public peace, health, and safety, and to preserve the lives and property of the people of Fulton County and to carry out the functions, duties, and responsibilities contained in the Federal Civil Defense Act of 1950 (Public Law 81-920) and the Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981 (O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.), it is hereby found and declared to be necessary to: 
(1)  Create a department of emergency management services for Fulton County; 
(2)  Authorize this department to take such steps as are necessary and appropriate to carry out the provisions of this law so that all emergency management functions for Fulton County are coordinated to the maximum practical extent with the comparable functions of the State of Georgia and its political subdivisions, of the federal government including its various departments and agencies, of other states and localities, and of private agencies, of every type, to the end that the most effective preparation and use may be made of the available manpower, resources, and facilities in dealing with any emergency or disaster that may occur. 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-1) 
Sec. 130-33. - Atlanta-Fulton County Emergency Management Agency designated as county department of emergency management services. 
The Atlanta-Fulton County Emergency Management Agency is hereby designated as the Fulton County Department of Emergency Management Services, to coordinate the planning and execution of all emergency management functions for Fulton County in accordance with the Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981 (O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.), as heretofore and hereafter amended from time to time. 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-3) 
Sec. 130-34. - Emergency management director; appointment. 
(a)  The department shall be under the direction and control of an emergency management director who shall be appointed by the Governor of the State of Georgia upon nomination by the Chairman of the Fulton County Board of Commissioners and the Mayor of the City of Atlanta, in accordance with the laws of the State of Georgia. 
(b)  The director of emergency management is also designated the disaster coordinator for Fulton County. 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-4) 
Sec. 130-35. - Policy development and implementation. 
(a)  The department and the director shall operate under policies established by the Fulton County Board of Commissioners and the county manager. The emergency management director shall be responsible directly to the Fulton County Board of Commissioners and the county manager and shall serve as the director of emergency and disaster planning for the county, to include planning required for the management of resources and economic stabilization in the event of enemy attack, planning required for mitigation, response and recovery operations for natural disasters, and coordination of emergency planning with Georgia and federal planning agencies. 
(b)  The emergency management director shall serve as the senior liaison officer between Fulton County and the State of Georgia Department of Defense and state and federal military forces. 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-5) 
Sec. 130-36. - Director's duties. 
(a)  The emergency management director is hereby authorized and directed to: 
(1)  Represent Fulton County in all matters pertaining to emergency management and disaster preparedness; 
(2)  Utilize all other department heads and all county officials as required in the preparation, development, and execution of emergency management plans; 
(3)  Assist county officials in planning the organization of county departments for emergency operations; 
(4)  Develop and maintain emergency management plans, in conjunction with county departments, for emergency functions in consonance with state and federal emergency plans, and to implement these plans when required; 
(5)  Establish an emergency management plan for the continuity of county government in the event of any enemy attack or other emergency; 
(6)  Maintain and, where feasible, improve public fallout shelters, and the attack warning system; maintain a community shelter plan in readiness for publication on short notice; train fallout shelter managers and radiological monitoring personnel; take such other readiness steps toward preparedness against enemy attack as are prudent and practical; and to institute equivalent readiness measures and planning against manmade and natural disasters; 
(7)  Maintain an adequate emergency communications system encompassing all county departments and other agencies and an emergency operations center; and 
(8)  Establish and maintain an organization of sufficient staff and operating agencies to implement approved emergency plans, approximately as set forth in section 130-38. 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-6) 
Sec. 130-37. - Organization and functions. 
The county manager is hereby authorized and directed to: 
(1)  Provide policy guidance to the director in the administration of the emergency management program; 
(2)  Assist in providing effective mobilization of all private and public resources of the county in time of emergency; 
(3)  Prepare and recommend for approval by the Fulton County Commission all resolutions, regulations, and ordinances necessary or convenient to implement the emergency management program; 
(4)  Review emergency management plans prepared by the department; and 
(5)  Approve the annual operating budget request of the department and approve other special emergency management services fund requests. 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-7) 
_____
Sec. 130-38. - Emergency management services. 
The emergency management organization shall consist of governmental and voluntary emergency services. The chief officer of a governmental service unit shall be the head of the department providing the service as an emergency management function. Directors of volunteer services shall be chosen by the director. Services shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 

 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-8) 
_____
Sec. 130-39. - Additional duties of director. 
The emergency management services director shall: 
(1)  Coordinate the operations and actions of all the services in time of emergency; 
(2)  Maintain a permanent staff sufficient to carry out the duties and responsibilities of the department and ensure that the staff is professionally trained and fully qualified; 
(3)  Ensure that an adequate emergency operations center (EOC) is available and properly equipped as needed for the conduct of emergency operations; 
(4)  Through coordination with the state emergency management division department of public defense and the Federal Emergency Management Agency, ensure that county plans and activities are consistent with state and federal guidelines; 
(5)  Prepare and periodically update basic emergency operations plan, to include an annex (plan) for each service which shall be prepared and authenticated by the service chief; and 
(6)  Plan and implement preparedness measures in readiness for implementation of emergency plans. 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-9) 
Sec. 130-40. - Budgets; financial records. 
(a)  The director shall be the chief executive officer and responsible administrator of the emergency management services department. 
(b)  The director shall prepare all budgets to meet operating and administrative expenses and shall operate the department in accordance with the approved budget appropriations of Fulton County to include anticipated federal matching funds, as projected by the Georgia Emergency Management Division, Department of Public Defense, with staff pay based upon an approved emergency management staffing pattern and pay scales of the Georgia Merit System. Proposed budget requests shall be approved by the Fulton County Manager. 
(c)  Financial records, personnel and administration records, and such other records as are desired, shall be subject to audit at any time by designated county officials. 
(Code 1983, § 27-4-10) 
Secs. 130-41—130-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) ---

DIVISION 2. - BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Boards, commissions, etc., § 102-601 et seq. 

Sec. 130-91. - Creation. 
The Fulton County Board of Commissioners hereby creates the Fulton County Emergency Medical Services Board. 
Sec. 130-92. - Membership; terms. 
(a)  The membership of the Fulton County Emergency Medical Services Board shall be comprised of the Fulton County Fire Chief, the Fulton County Director of Public Health, the Fulton County Chief of Police, the Fulton County Director of Emergency Medical Services, the Fulton County Director of 911 Communications, a representative from the City of Atlanta, a board certified emergency medical physician, and other members for such terms as may be appointed by the Fulton County Board of Commissioners. 
(b)  The Fulton County Board of Commissioners shall appoint the physician to the emergency medical services board and that the representative from the City of Atlanta shall be appointed by mayor of the City of Atlanta for such terms as delineated by the Fulton County Board of Commissioners. 
(94-RM-766, 12-7-94) 
Sec. 130-93. - Director. 
The Fulton County Emergency Medical Services Board shall be served by an executive director who shall also serve as the Fulton County Director of Emergency Medical Services and who shall be responsible for implementing the policies and procedures of that board. 
(94-RM-766, 12-7-94) 
Sec. 130-94. - Functions. 
(a)  The Fulton County Board of Commissioners recognizes that the State of Georgia, through the region III emergency medical services council, has the sole authority and responsibility for administering the emergency medical systems communications program within Fulton County. However, the Fulton County Emergency Medical Services Board shall advise the board of commissioners concerning appropriate recommendations to be made to the region III emergency medical services council. The Fulton County Emergency Medical Services Board shall address and concern itself with recommending appropriate policies and procedures to guide the Fulton County Emergency Medical System; exploring adequate performance standards, and the possibility of sanctions, penalties and/or incentives for providers within the system; evaluating the cost and quality of emergency medical service being provided to the citizens of Fulton County; and performing such other tasks as may be assigned by the Fulton County Manager and/or the Board of Commissioners. 
(b)  The board of commissioners may enact rules and regulations governing the Fulton County Emergency Medical Services Board, but the enactment of such rules shall not be construed as designating the Fulton County Emergency Medical Services Board as a legal entity capable of entering into contracts or being sued. 
(94-RM-766, 12-7-94) 
Chapter 134 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 134-1. - Hazardous material advisory council. 
(a)  There is established the Hazardous Material Advisory Council of Fulton County which shall be composed of members from the following county agencies:

(2)  Sheriff of Fulton County; 
(3)  Fulton County Health Department; 
(4)  Atlanta-Fulton County EMA; 
(5)  Fulton County Legal Counsel; 
(6)  Fulton County Fire Department; and 
(7)  Fulton County Communications. 
(b)  The Atlanta-Fulton County Emergency Management Agency shall solicit additional participation for the Hazardous Material Advisory Council of Fulton County by inviting the following organizations to also become members: 
(1)  Fire department from each of the incorporated cities of Fulton County; 
(2)  Atlanta Chamber of Commerce; 
(3)  Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority (MARTA); 
(4)  National Defense Transportation Association (NDTA); 
(5)  Atlanta Bureau of Pollution Control; 
(6)  American Red Cross; 
(7)  Business and industry representatives; 
(8)  Fulton DeKalb Hospital Authority; 
(9)  Public information group representative (media); 
(10)  Community group representative; and 
(11)  Technical experts. 
(c)  The council shall: 
(1)  Pursue the development of an awareness program involving industry, the community, local government and the news media; and 
(2)  Evaluate available resources for preparing for and responding to potential incidents. 
(d)  The Atlanta-Fulton County Emergency Management Agency shall be responsible as a consultant to the hazardous material advisory council and shall furnish all administrative support attendant to council activities. 
(Res. of 6-1-88) 
Cross reference— Boards, commissions, etc., § 102-601 et seq.

Sec. 138-31. - Professional services. 
To the extent that the duties of the medical examiner will permit him to accept outside professional work, the medical examiner should be permitted to engage in the same. Professional work includes, but is not necessarily limited to, the following: 
(1)  Lectures on professional subjects; 
(2)  Limited teaching engagements; 
(3)  Expert testimony for third persons where no other qualified pathologist in this area could perform the same work and for the same purpose; and 
(4)  Attendance at professional meetings, including meetings of the medical society and particular disciplines of the medical examiner. 
(Code 1983, § 23-2-32)

Sec. 138-71. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created a body corporate and politic to be known as the Fulton-DeKalb Hospital Authority, which said authority shall consist of a board of ten trustees, with all the powers, privileges, immunities, rights, and liabilities as provided by law. 
(Code 1983, § 13-2-11) 
Sec. 138-72. - Members; terms of office. 
The terms of members of the authority shall be for four years. 
(Code 1983, § 13-2-12) 
Sec. 138-73. - Appointees of City of Atlanta; submission of names by Mayor of Atlanta. 
The Mayor of the City of Atlanta may submit to the Commissioners of Fulton County and DeKalb County the names of not more than five members which he recommends the commissioners of the respective counties appoint to serve on the board of trustees. Should persons recommended by the Mayor of the City of Atlanta be appointed by the Commissioners of Fulton and DeKalb Counties, the Mayor of the City of Atlanta shall likewise recommend to the commissioners successors to such appointees in the event of vacancy or the expiration of the term of office of any such trustee or trustees. 
(Code 1983, § 13-2-13) 
Sec. 138-74. - Relevant jurisdiction. 
The area of operation of the Fulton-DeKalb Hospital Authority is hereby defined as including all the territorial limits and affecting all the citizens within the limits of the boundaries of said counties. 
(Code 1983, § 13-2-14) 
Sec. 138-75. - Contracts with commissioners. 
The board of commissioners shall enter into negotiations with said authority for the use of the services and facilities of the authority and for the construction and maintenance thereof and the execution of a contract or contracts in connection therewith, as may be deemed necessary and advisable to accomplish the purposes hereby intended. 
(Code 1983, § 13-2-15)

DIVISION 4. - FULCO HOSPITAL AUTHORITY 

Sec. 138-111. - Declaration of need. 
There is hereby determined and declared to be a pressing, existing, and future need for an additional hospital authority (as more fully described and defined in the Hospital Authorities Law, and more specifically O.C.G.A. § 31-7-73), to function in Fulton County for the purpose of providing adequate and proper public health facilities in said area, thereby promoting the general welfare of the citizenry. 
(Code 1983, § 13-2-31) 
Sec. 138-112. - Creation. 
There is hereby activated the public body corporate and politic known as the Fulco Hospital Authority, which was created upon the adoption and approval of the Hospital Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 31-7-73. 
(Code 1983, § 13-2-32) 
Sec. 138-113. - Appointment of trustees; service till successor appointed. 
(a)  Upon the termination of the term of office of any trustee for any reason, the board of commissioners shall fill any vacancy on the board of trustees of the hospital authority in the following manner: 
(1)  The board of commissioners shall submit a list of three eligible persons to the board of trustees of the hospital authority. 
(2)  The board of trustees of the hospital authority at its next regular meeting shall select one of the three persons named in said list. 
(b)  If, at the end of any term of office of any trustee, a successor thereto shall have not been elected, then the trustee whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until his successor shall be so elected. 
(Code 1983, § 13-2-33) 
Sec. 138-114. - Organization; operations. 
The board of trustees hereinbefore elected shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities, and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Hospital Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq.), as it now exists and as it might hereafter be amended or modified. 
(Code 1983, § 13-2-34)

Chapter 146 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Justice system coordinating committee, § 102-631 et seq.; resolutions pertaining to courts, ch. 122; mandatory drug testing of public safety and law enforcement employees and employees carrying firearm, § 154-8. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 146-1. - Policies governing use of force. 
(a)  The board of commissioners does hereby state, clarify, and reiterate the policies governing the use of force by peace officers employed by Fulton County as follows: 
(1)  In effectuating an arrest, peace officers shall only use such force as is reasonably necessary to effectuate the arrest. 
(2)  Peace officers shall only threaten or use force against another when, and to the extent, that he or she reasonably believes that such threat or force is necessary to defend himself, herself, or a third person against such others' eminent use of unlawful force. 
(3)  Peace officers shall only be justified in using force which is intended or likely to cause death or great bodily harm if he or she reasonably believes that such force is necessary to prevent death or great bodily injury to himself, herself, or a third person, or to prevent the commission of a forcible felony. 
(4)  All peace officers shall be required to submit a written report of any use of force to their respective chief, sheriff, or marshal. 
(b)  The law enforcement agencies under the jurisdiction of the Board of Commissioners of Fulton County shall continue to ensure, through training and monitoring, that peace officers comply with the above-stated policies of subsection (a) of this section. 
(93-RC-214, 6-16-93) 
Secs. 146-2—146-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to provide for police protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(1); Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; county police, O.C.G.A. § 36-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 146-31. - Fulton County Police Force established to full operation. 
Police protection for unincorporated Fulton County shall be provided by an independent Fulton County Police Force established as follows: 
(1)  The Fulton County Police Force shall be under the supervision, direction, and command of the county police chief who shall be appointed by the Board of Commissioners of Fulton County and who shall report to the county manager. The term of office of the county police chief shall be fixed by the board of commissioners. 
(2)  The salary of the county police chief shall be not less than $25,000.00 per year. 
(3)  The county manager, together with the county police chief when appointed, shall develop, subject to the approval of the board of commissioners, rules, regulations, and procedures for the establishment, direction, and operation of the county police force. Said procedure shall provide for recruitment, training, and equipping of adequate forces to give full police protection to the county, and shall further include procedures providing for protection of pension and retirement rights, orderly advancement and promotion policy, and other employee benefits commensurate with existing county policies, and such other procedures as are necessary to implement the establishment of the Fulton County Police Force with full operating capacity. 
(Code 1983, § 27-1-1) 
Sec. 146-32. - Departmental regulations. 
The rules and regulations of the Fulton County Police Department approved by the board of commissioners July 25, 1979, and effective August 15, 1979, are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference. Copies of those regulations are on file in the police department and in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1983, § 27-1-2) 
Sec. 146-33. - Unclaimed property; authority to sell at auction. 
(a)  Generally. The county police department shall have the authority to sell, at public outcry, to the highest bidder for cash any and all the articles of personal property that have come into their hands and which, after diligent effort has been made to ascertain the true owner thereof without success, remain unclaimed for a period of 60 days. 
(b)  Records required. It shall be the duty of the Fulton County Police Department to maintain a separate and complete catalog record of all property coming into their hands, such property to be identified in detail by its usual name, make and model, manufacturer's name and serial number, if any, and if no identifying name or numbers, to be fully described on the catalog record as to its physical properties and appearance. The record shall also show the date the property came into the hands of the department and the disposal thereof. 
(c)  Responsibility to try to find owner. It shall be the duty of the county police department to make a diligent effort to find the true owner of any article of personal property coming into their hands and if an owner can be found, to deliver the property to him. In the event that the true owner of any article cannot be found and the property remains unclaimed for a period of not less than 60 days next preceding the date of sale as hereinafter provided, the department may proceed to sell any article or articles as hereinafter provided. 
(d)  When sale conducted; terms of sale. On the first Monday in February, the first Monday in May, the first Monday in August, and the first Monday in November, in each year, the county police department shall hold a public sale of all unclaimed articles of personal property held by them for at least 60 days immediately preceding the date of sale at the headquarters of the county police department or any other location that may be designated by the county police department. All articles sold shall be sold for cash to the highest bidder on an as is basis, and no warranties of any nature, either express or implied, either as to merchantable title, quality, or performance as made by the Fulton County Police Department. 
(e)  Advertisement of sale. The sale referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation in the county once each week for two weeks immediately preceding the next sale date. The advertisement shall be of sufficient size and type to be easily read and understood by the general public and shall state definitely the time and place of the sale; that it shall be open to the public; and, that all sales are to be made to the highest bidder for cash. The advertisement may refer to the sale as an "ole hoss" sale or by any other appropriate name, and shall state that only unclaimed property which has come into the possession of the Fulton County Police Department is being sold; that the department makes no warranties whatsoever, either express or implied as to merchantable title, quality, or performance; and all articles are sold as is. 
(f)  Conduct of sale. The Fulton County Police Department shall appoint a licensed auctioneer, a member of its own force, or any other individual to conduct the sale under the guidance of an employee of the department and more than one such person may act at any sale, either alternately or at the same time, as the circumstances may dictate, and in the discretion of the employee of the department who is in charge of the sale. The auctioneer or other individual acting shall be the sole arbiter in the case of a disputed sale, and he shall not make a sale until all bidding on the article offered has ceased. However, there shall be no required number of bids before a sale is made. 
(g)  Announcement to be made at sale. It shall be the duty of the auctioneer or other person holding the sale to make public announcement before opening the sale that the Fulton County Police Department does not warrant title to any article, nor is there any other warranty, either expressed or implied, as to any article sold; that all sales are final; and all articles are sold as is. It shall be the duty of the auctioneer or other person in charge to make this announcement at intervals during the progress of the sales. 
(h)  Disposition of proceeds. It shall be the duty of the Fulton County Police Department to make a true accounting to the finance department of all the property sold and money collected from the sale conducted as provided herein, which money shall be deposited in the general fund and used as the law prescribes. 
(Code 1983, § 27-1-3) 
Secs. 146-34—146-60. - Reserved.

Sec. 146-81. - Establishment. 
The sheriff is hereby authorized to establish a bank account in the name of county jail welfare fund, for recording all concession purchases, sales, and all other welfare disbursements, and all funds for the welfare of persons committed to the jail shall be promptly deposited in said account, and not less than twice weekly. 
(Code 1983, § 27-2-11) 
Sec. 146-82. - Committee established to take responsibility for purchases. 
A committee composed of the sheriff, the chief jailer, and the chairman of the board of commissioners or his appointee is hereby established, who shall be responsible for all items purchased out of the welfare fund. 
(Code 1983, § 27-2-12) 
Sec. 146-83. - Duties of jail food supervisor. 
The jail food supervisor shall be responsible for all concession purchases from a list approved by the committee and all concession sales, and may designate a salaried deputy sheriff to assist him, provided the name of this employee is recorded in an appropriate record of daily sales. The food supervisor shall have continuing responsibility for all inventory, sales, and money relating to the welfare fund. 
(Code 1983, § 27-2-13) 
Sec. 146-84. - Financial records. 
All purchases and other disbursement shall be made by check signed by the chief jailor and countersigned by the sheriff. All financial records relating to said welfare fund shall be approved and audited by the internal audit division of the comptroller's office and also subject to the general county audit. 
(Code 1983, § 27-2-14)
