(6)  Finance director; 
(7)  Fire chief; 
(8)  Director of grounds; 
(9)  Health commissioner; 
(10)  Director of inspections and permits; 
(11)  Juvenile court judge; 
(12)  Land agent; 
(13)  County attorney; 
(14)  Library director; 
(15)  Marshal (incumbent on May 20, 1987, only); 
(16)  Medical examiner; 
(17)  Director of parks and recreation; 
(18)  Personnel director; 
(19)  Director of planning and economic development; 
(20)  Police chief; 
(21)  Director of public buildings; 
(22)  Public defender; 
(23)  Director of public information; 
(24)  Director of public works; 
(25)  Purchasing agent; 
(26)  Elections supervisor; 
(27)  State court clerk; 
(28)  Superior court administrator; 
(29)  Tax assessor; 
(30)  Tax commissioner; and 
(31)  Zoning director. 
(c)  All elected officials whose compensation is paid, in whole or in part, by the Director of Finance of Fulton County and the department heads specified in subsection (b) of this section shall be entitled to the pension benefits calculated in accordance with subdivision IV of this division upon their retirement from active county employment. However, such elected officials or department heads shall retire with the creditable service specified in and under the circumstances described in section 154-336(4). 
(d)  All sums needed to fund any actuarial deficit created by the foregoing provisions shall be paid from general county funds to the pension fund from which any of the above individuals receives pension payments. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-46) 
Sec. 154-317. - Persons ineligible to participate in pension fund. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the provisions of section 154-316, the following persons shall be ineligible to participate in the pension fund established by this division: 
(1)  Temporary or casual employees of Fulton County. 
(2)  Employees of Fulton County hired on a contract basis for a specific task. 
(3)  Elected officials who shall waive in writing the right to participate in pension funds maintained by Fulton County, in the manner provided by law. 
(4)  Poll officers and election workers who are not regular employees of Fulton County. 
(5)  Any person who shall be a contributing member or who shall be drawing pension benefits or has vested his rights under any pension fund maintained in whole or in part by Fulton County or from funds of Fulton County. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this division, any person initially participating in the plan established hereby shall not be entitled to any pension benefit for himself or any beneficiary if he shall have been discharged from county employment for cause. The sole benefit which such individual shall receive will be a refund of contributions made to the pension fund established hereunder without interest. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-47) 
Sec. 154-318. - Compulsory participation. 
Participation in the pension fund created by this division shall be compulsory for all eligible persons specified in section 154-316, and not excluded by section 154-317, who shall become employed or reemployed by Fulton County on or after the effective date of this division. Participation shall also be compulsory as to any employee of Fulton County employed prior to the effective date of this division if such employee shall have filed an election to participate in this fund, as provided in subdivision VII of this division. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-48) 
Sec. 154-319. - Contributions by participants. 
There shall be deducted from the total salary of any officer or employee participating under the provisions of this plan the sum of eight percent which shall include provision for payment of a pension to a beneficiary. Deductions required by this section shall be effective with the effective date of this division, or with the initial date of the employment of the participant, whichever date shall later occur. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-49) 
Sec. 154-320. - Employer contributions. 
(a)  In addition to the funds derived from deductions from salaries and wages as required by section 154-319, it shall be the duty of the governing authority of Fulton County to appropriate and pay into the pension fund each year an amount which shall be equal to the actuarially determined percentage of members' salary and wages necessary to pay the normal cost contribution of benefits earned by members and to amortize the unfunded accrued liability of the pension fund within 40 years after deduction of contributions required of officers and employees. 
(b)  For the purposes of paying the required employer contributions provided above, the governing authority of Fulton County shall be authorized to levy ad valorem taxes to pay to the pension fund sufficient to amortize the unfunded accrued liability under the provisions of this division within 40 years from the effective date of this division. 
(c)  Should said pension fund at any time be insufficient to meet and pay the pension due to such officers and employees, the governing authority of Fulton County shall appropriate from current funds amounts sufficient to make up the deficiency as it relates to the respective officers and employees, and deposit the same into said pension fund. 
(d)  Provided, however, commencing with the effective date of this division, the required employer contribution shall be not less than ten percent of the salaries and wages of members of this pension fund. Commencing January 1, 1983, and each January 1 thereafter, the required employer contribution shall be increased by at least one percent of salary and wages of members of the pension fund until such increase of one percent would exceed the actuarially determined contribution rate provided above and at such time, and thereafter, the required employer contribution rate shall be the actuarially determined employer contribution rate. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-50) 
Secs. 154-321—154-335. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - Benefits 

Sec. 154-336. - Normal retirement benefits. 
All officers and employees of Fulton County who shall be participants under this plan and who shall retire as a matter of right from creditable service shall receive a monthly pension benefit hereinafter set forth and referred to as a "normal monthly pension benefit." Such normal monthly pension benefit shall be equal to two percent of such person's average monthly earnings multiplied by the number of such person's average monthly earnings multiplied by the number of such person's years, or fraction thereof, of creditable service, or in the case of the individuals specified in subsection (4) of this section, a minimum of $500.00 per month. Years of creditable service shall include accumulated unused sick leave days credited to such employee or officer, not to exceed a total of 90 working days or 4½ months' maximum. The following classes of persons shall be entitled to a normal monthly pension benefit upon their retirement from active service: 
(1)  Individuals 60 years of age or older with 15 years of creditable service; 
(2)  Individuals 65 years of age or older with ten years of creditable service; 
(3)  Individuals 55 years of age or older with 30 years of creditable service; 
(4)  Any elected official or department head participating in the Fulton County Employees' Pension Fund who shall resign, shall fail to be reelected, or to offer for reelection, or shall fail to be reappointed, or shall be removed by operation of law, or who shall be requested to resign their office or whose office shall be abolished, provided that such individual has at least ten years of creditable service; or 
(5)  Current average cost-of-living index. Any individual who is retired by operation of law with ten or more years of actual service, with the exception of individuals whose employment is terminated for cause. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-56) 
Sec. 154-337. - Average monthly earnings. 
For the purpose of computing all benefits under this plan, average monthly earnings shall be the average of the monthly earnings of the highest three years' salary or earnings during the terms of employment or, in the case of individuals specified in section 154-336(4), the highest monthly earnings attained by the person or officer during his employment. In computing the average monthly earnings, if the officer or employee shall have received a lump sum payment for compensation, accumulated vacation, sick leave, bonus pay, or similar benefits, the amount of such payment shall be equally distributed over the period of time in which such compensation or benefit was earned or accumulated. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-57) 
Sec. 154-338. - Early retirement benefits. 
All persons who shall participate under this plan may, as a matter of right, retire from active service and receive an early retirement benefit, provided such person shall have served 15 years in the active service of such county. Such early retirement benefit shall be a pension equal to a normal monthly pension benefit less one-half of one percent per month for each month not to exceed 60 months that the officer or employee lacks in being 60 years of age, and one-quarter of one percent per month of each month in excess of 60 months that the officer or employee lacks in being 60 years of age, provided that no person shall be entitled to retire under the provisions of this section unless the pension benefit computed hereunder, less the penalties provided for, shall equal or exceed any minimum pension benefit which would be required to be paid to such person under other provisions of law; provided, however, as to any officer or employee coming under the terms of this division who was in the employment of Fulton County prior to the effective date of this division, such officer or employee may elect a monthly pension benefit, hereinafter referred to as "reduced monthly pension benefit," provided that such person shall have served 25 years and shall have attained the age of 55 years. Said reduced monthly pension benefit shall be equal to a normal pension benefit, less 1/12 of two percent per month for each month the officer or employee lacks in being 60 years of age. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-58) 
Sec. 154-339. - Vested monthly pension benefits. 
Whenever any person participating under this plan shall have completed at least ten years of active service with such county and not yet have reached the age of 65 years, then such person shall have the right to terminate such person's employment with such county, elect not to withdraw or have paid to such person the amount which said person would have paid into the pension fund prior to terminating such person's employment, and upon subsequently attaining 65 years of age, commence to receive at said time and be paid a monthly pension benefit hereinafter referred to as a "vested monthly pension benefit" which shall be the same amount which such individual would have received had he retired at age 65; provided, however, that no person shall be entitled to benefits under this section, unless the benefits to which he would be entitled at age 65 would equal or exceed any minimum pension benefit which would be required to be paid to such person under other provisions of law at the time that such person terminated his employment with the county. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-59) 
Sec. 154-340. - Limitation on amount of benefits. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 154-336 through 154-339, no pension benefits shall be initially awardable and be payable to any person who shall retire under the provisions of this division which shall exceed 75 percent of the average monthly earnings of such person as hereinabove defined. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-60) 
Sec. 154-341. - Cost of living adjustment. 
Any person receiving a pension payment under the provisions of this division or his beneficiaries shall be entitled to cost-of-living adjustments as hereinafter set forth. As used herein, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Current average cost-of-living index means the average of the monthly Consumer Price Index for the 12-month period from November 1 through October 31, prior to the annual adjustment date, as determined by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor for all items and major groups, United States city average. 
(2)  Pensioner base index means the average of the Consumer Price Index for the 12-month period ending two months prior to the date of retirement for any participant who retires under the provisions of this division. In the event the base year used in computing the monthly Consumer Price Index should be changed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the board of trustees shall, with the advice of an independent actuary, adjust the pensioner base index of each retired pensioner and of each pensioner or beneficiary, with benefit payments commencing during the first year in which such change was made, so as to effect the original intent of this section in an equitable manner. 
(3)  Adjusted pensioner index means the pensioner base index adjusted, on a cumulative basis, for all percentage adjustments made in benefits prior to the current annual adjustment date. The adjusted pensioner index and the pensioner base index shall be applicable to any beneficiary becoming entitled to benefits under this resolution in the same manner as they would have been applicable to the pensioner had such pensioner continued in life. 
(4)  Annual adjustment date means January 1 of each year. The board of trustees shall ascertain the current average cost-of-living index as of January 1 each year, and the benefits being paid under this resolution shall be adjusted as of the annual adjustment date as follows: 
a.  If the current average cost-of-living index is less than 100 percent of the adjusted pensioner index, such person's basic benefit shall be reduced by a percentage equal to the difference between 100 percent and the percentage representing the current average cost-of-living index divided by his adjusted pensioner index. 
b.  If the current average cost-of-living index is less than 100 percent of the adjusted pensioner index, such person's basic benefit shall be reduced by a percentage equal to the difference between 100 percent and the percentage representing the current average cost-of-living index divided by his adjusted pensioner index. 
(5)  Current average cost-of-living index. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this subsection, no increase or decrease in the amount of the monthly retirement benefit due to changes in the current average cost-of-living index, effective at any annual adjustment date, shall be in excess of three percent of the amount of the monthly retirement benefit payable immediately prior to such date. Neither shall the provisions of this subsection be applied so as to reduce the amount of the benefits of a pensioner or beneficiary of an amount less than that to which such pensioner or beneficiary would be entitled to receive under the other provisions of this division. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-61) 
Sec. 154-342. - Disability. 
In the event that any member, who is not otherwise entitled to a pension under this division and who shall become totally and permanently disabled by reason of injury, ill health, age, or infirmity, and who shall have ten or more years of creditable service or shall become totally disabled in line of duty, he shall be entitled to receive a disability pension based upon the same formula as computing a normal pension benefit, regardless of the age of such individual. Said pension shall be payable during life and the continuation of such disability. Such pension shall be granted only upon certification of at least two physicians, one of who shall be a county physician. The board of trustees shall have authority to make such rules and regulations as may be necessary to determine the procedure for the grant of disability pensions and the continuation of the same. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-62) 
Sec. 154-343. - Refunds. 
Should any person participating in the pension plan established by this division die, resign or be dismissed from the county service of the county without having received or becoming eligible to receive a pension of any kind and without having a qualified beneficiary entitled to a pension to be paid from the pension fund, such person or his estate shall be entitled to a refund of all of the person's contributions made pursuant to this division. Any participant may file a written designation with the executive secretary of the pension board specifying any person whether related to him or not, who shall be entitled to receive a refund of the contribution made by him in the event of his death. In the event this privilege is exercised by participant, then such refund shall be made to the person so designated and not to his personal representative. In the event that any participant in the pension plan established by this division shall commence to receive pension benefits and shall die or cease to be eligible for such pension benefits or his or her beneficiary shall cease to be eligible for such pension benefits and the total amount paid in pension benefits to such individual and his beneficiaries shall not equal the amount of contributions made by such individual to the pension fund established hereby, then the excess over the amount paid to such individual shall be refunded to the person or representative of such contributor or his designee as specified in this section. In the event that any person shall receive a refund of contributions, such person shall not be able to claim the period of time for which such refund was made unless he shall repay such refund in full, plus interest thereon from the date of refund. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-63) 
Sec. 154-344. - Mandatory repayment of refunds. 
Any person who shall have received a refund of pension contributions upon termination of county employment who shall be reemployed by the county within six months from the date that such refund was made must repay such refund, plus interest thereon, from the date of refund. Such refund may be repaid in such number of installments as may be determined by such individual, not exceeding 60. Interest under this section shall be at the annual rate of return determined by the board of trustees under the provisions of section 154-379 for the period of time that said refund was unpaid. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-64) 
Secs. 154-345—154-360. - Reserved. 
Subdivision V. - Beneficiaries 

Sec. 154-361. - Authorized beneficiaries. 
The authorized beneficiary of a participant in this plan shall be the surviving spouse of such participant. In the event there is no surviving spouse, then the authorized beneficiary shall be the child or children of such participant under the age of 18 years. Benefits shall be payable equally to all children of such participant under the age of 18 years. Benefits shall be payable to a surviving spouse during the term of his or her natural life, so long as he or she shall remain unmarried. After the death of a surviving spouse, benefits shall be payable to children under the age of 18 years, until such time as the youngest surviving child shall reach the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-71) 
Sec. 154-362. - Beneficiary benefits. 
Pensions for beneficiaries designated by individuals participating under the terms of this plan shall be three-quarters of the amount the pensioner was receiving at the time of his death, or the amount which such individual would have received had he retired with a normal pension benefit to which such person would have been entitled had he survived to age 65. Such benefits shall be payable to the beneficiary designated under this division, commencing with the date of death of the participant under this plan. However, if said beneficiary is more than five years younger than the pensioner, there shall be deducted from the beneficiary pension 1/12 of two percent per month for each month that such beneficiary is more than five years younger than the pensioner. However, said deduction of 1/12 of two percent per month shall not apply if the beneficiary is 60 years of age, or more, at the time of becoming eligible for benefits. No person shall be entitled to receive beneficiary benefits as a surviving spouse unless he or she shall have been married to the participant under this plan at least one year prior to the time he or she would otherwise become eligible for beneficiary benefits. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-72) 
Secs. 154-363—154-375. - Reserved. 
Subdivision VI. - Creditable Service 

Sec. 154-376. - Current Fulton County service. 
Creditable service shall include all service rendered by a participant in the pension fund created by this division to Fulton County following the effective date of this division, provided that all employee contributions are made. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-76) 
Sec. 154-377. - Previous service with Fulton County; credit for temporary and C.E.T.A. service. 
(a)  Previous service. Creditable service shall include all service rendered by a participant to Fulton County prior to the effective date of this division, provided that such participant shall have been a member of a pension fund maintained by Fulton County during such period of service and shall have paid or shall pay the maximum employee contribution which was required by law to be paid by participants in the pension fund in which such individual participated. To receive credit for such service, a participant shall in writing renounce all benefits under any other pension plan maintained by Fulton County, and shall authorize the transfer of contributions made to a previous pension plan to the pension fund created by this division. In the event that such participant shall have withdrawn his pension contributions, or in the event that such participant shall fail to have paid the full amount required by this section, then such participant shall pay directly to the pension fund the entire amount required by this section, together with interest from the end of the calendar year in which such pension contributions were withdrawn or in which such contributions were not paid. Any individual who shall be employed by Fulton County on the effective date of this division must comply with the provisions of section 154-397 in order to receive credit for prior service with Fulton County. 
(b)  Credit for temporary service and C.E.T.A. service with Fulton County. Notwithstanding any other provision of this division, an individual shall be entitled to claim credit for temporary service and C.E.T.A. service with Fulton County as creditable service under this division under the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Such service must have been for full-time, continuous employment by Fulton County. 
(2)  Such service must have immediately preceded and led into permanent employment by Fulton County and participation under the terms of this division. 
(3)  The person claiming such service shall pay the same employee contribution which such person would have paid had he been participating in the pension fund established by this division during such period of temporary service with the same compensation as he was receiving at the time of claiming such credit. Such sum shall be matched by Fulton County. 
(4)  In the event that the sums paid under subsection (b)(3) of this section shall not be sufficient to fund the actuarial liability created by the allowance of the credit authorized by this section, any additional sums which may be necessary shall be paid by Fulton County from general funds. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-77) 
Sec. 154-378. - Previous service with other employers. 
Any participant in the pension fund established by this division who was employed by the State of Georgia or was a member of the General Assembly of Georgia or was employed by a municipality located, in whole or in part, in Fulton County, or who was employed by the Fulton County Board of Education or the Atlanta-Fulton County Recreation Authority, or who was an active member of the United States armed forces may claim credit for such service rendered prior to his employment with Fulton County, a year of such service counting for purposes of this division the year of service in Fulton County upon the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  No credit shall be given for part-time or temporary service. 
(2)  When such participant has served five years with Fulton County, he shall be eligible to receive credit for any periods of prior service and not to exceed ten years when combined with any other prior service, other than military, claimed hereunder. 
(3)  Application must be made for prior service credit within six months after first becoming eligible for claiming such service, or six months after the effective date of this section, whichever date shall be later. Any participant who does not claim prior service under this section within said period of six months shall pay into the pension fund interest computed under subsection (7) of this section on the total amount due the fund from six months following the date such person first became eligible to claim such service. 
(4)  To obtain prior service credit, such participant shall pay into the pension fund, in addition to all other sums required by this article, a sum representing 12 percent of his total salary during such period of time, plus six percent of such total amounts. 
(5)  No years of credit allowed under this section shall be used to obtain pension benefits in any other pension system supported, in whole or in part, with public funds. 
(6)  It shall be the responsibility of the officer or employee taking application for such credit to furnish to the board of trustees proof for the years of service and the monthly rate of compensation in such manner as the board may by rule prescribe. 
(7)  Interest to be charged under the provisions of subsection (3) of this section shall be at the rate of earnings of the pension fund from six months following the time such employee first became eligible to claim such service until the actual date of election. 
(8)  Sums due hereunder may be payable in such number of monthly installments (not exceeding 60) as may be determined by the pension board. However, such installments shall bear interest at a rate equal to the rate of return of the pension fund for the year preceding the date of such election to pay in installments and, further, payment of all sums due hereunder shall be made in full prior to the receipt of pension payments. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-78) 
Sec. 154-379. - Payment in installments. 
Any payments due to the pension fund created by this division and the terms of this subdivision of this division, may be paid in equal monthly installments not to exceed 60. Such installments shall bear interest at a rate equal to the average return on the pension fund investments for the fiscal year preceding the date in which the election to pay in installments is made. Such average rate of return shall be determined annually by the board of trustees of the pension fund created hereby for the year 1981, and such rate of return shall be that earned by the Fulton County General Employees' Pension Fund. The amounts shall be deducted from any compensation due the participant or from pension payments. The board of trustees shall require an assignment of a life insurance policy in an amount at least equal to the amount due to the pension fund or the maximum amount of life insurance provided to the participant by Fulton County. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-79) 
Secs. 154-380—154-395. - Reserved. 
Subdivision VII. - Miscellaneous Provisions 

Sec. 154-396. - Effective date. 
This division shall become effective on January 1, 1982. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-86) 
Sec. 154-397. - Participation by existing employees. 
Employees of Fulton County on the payroll of the county prior to the effective date of this division shall not be required to participate in the pension fund created hereby. However, such employees may participate if they file a written election to participate in this fund, renouncing all other benefits under any other pension plan maintained by Fulton County and authorize the transfer to the fund created hereby of all contributions to the credit of such participant in any other pension fund maintained by Fulton County. In the event that such participant shall not have paid the maximum employee contribution required by law to be paid by participants in the pension funds in which such an individual previously participated or, in the event that such individual shall have withdrawn all or any part of such contribution, then such participant shall pay to the fund created by this division, the total amount which he would have contributed, less such amount as may be transferred by the pension fund in which he previously participated. Upon such authorization or payment, such participant shall be entitled to credit sole service for all years of service with which he was credited in the previous pension plan. In addition thereto, if the election of such participant is filed within six months following the effective date of this division, such participant shall be entitled to receive credit for all years of creditable service with Fulton County and years of service for employment by Fulton County or municipalities located, in whole or in part, in Fulton County, or public agencies required by law to be supported from funds of Fulton County, active service in the United States armed forces, and for service in the General Assembly of Georgia, a year of such service counting for the purposes of this resolution as a year of service in Fulton County, provided that such person shall have made the contributions required by section 1 of the act approved March 30, 1971, 1971 Ga. Laws, page 2309, as amended; provided, however, that no person shall receive more than ten years' prior service credit for service rendered to any employer other than Fulton County, plus actual military service not to exceed four years. In the event that such election to participate is filed prior to the effective date of this division, it shall be filed with the Executive Secretary of the Fulton County General Employees' Pension Board. In the event it is filed subsequent to the effective date of this division, it shall be filed with the executive secretary of the pension board created by this division. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-87) 
Sec. 154-398. - Additional payment for participation. 
In the event that any employee of Fulton County who was employed on the effective date of this division, shall fail to file the election required by section 154-397, on or before six months following the effective date of this division, such employee shall not be entitled to claim credit for any service rendered prior to his election to participate in the pension fund created by this division, unless he shall pay, in addition to the sums required by section 154-397, a sum which when added to the sums required to be paid by section 154-397 shall be sufficient to actuarially fund the benefit to which such individual shall become entitled to under the provisions of this division, plus the cost of the actuary for the pension fund for computing such sum. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-88) 
Sec. 154-399. - Installment payments. 
Payments required to be made under the provision of sections 154-397 and 154-398 may be made in installments bearing interest in the same manner as prescribed in section 154-379. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-89) 
Sec. 154-400. - Prohibition against receiving additional county compensation. 
No person receiving pension benefits under the provisions of this division shall receive any other compensation from Fulton County; provided, however, that nothing herein shall prohibit the receipt of workmen's compensation benefits, or payment to a pension as an election or poll worker. In addition, any person who shall have been awarded a pension under the provisions of this division may, upon written notification to the executive secretary of the pension board, cause his pension payments to be suspended during such period of time as he receives compensation from Fulton County. 
(Code 1983, § 24-3-90) 
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC SAFETY EMPLOYEES' PENSION PLAN OF 1977 

Sec. 154-401. - Board of trustees. 
The name of the system shall be the Fulton County Public Safety Employees' Pension Fund. It shall be governed by a board of trustees composed of five members, one of whom shall be a member of the board of commissioners, appointed by the chairman of the board of commissioners; one of whom shall be the county manager; one of whom shall be a citizen of Fulton County, who shall not be an employee of Fulton County and who shall be appointed by the county commission member and the county manager; one of whom shall be a member of the county police; and one of whom shall be a member of the county fire department. Both the policeman and the fireman members of the board of trustees shall be active members in good standing of the pension fund. The policeman member shall be elected by the policemen members of the fund, and the fireman member shall be elected by the firemen members of the fund, in February of each even-numbered year, and shall serve a term of two years, or until their successors are elected and qualified. The director of finance, or such person who shall perform the duties which are now performed by the director of finance, shall be the treasurer of the public safety employees' pension fund, and shall handle and disburse all funds in control of the board of trustees. The secretary of the public safety employees' fund shall be the secretary of the general employees' pension fund and shall perform such duties as may be necessary. It shall be the duty of the board of trustees of the public safety employees' pension fund to operate and maintain said fund for the benefit of the members of said fund. Said board of trustees shall meet at least once a month. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-1) 
Sec. 154-402. - Eligibility to participate. 
All persons employed by Fulton County as a policeman or a fireman shall be eligible to participate in the public safety employees' pension fund, provided, that such persons shall not have waived, in writing, the right to participate in pension funds maintained in whole or in part with funds of Fulton County. No person who is a participant in the public safety employees' pension fund shall participate in any other county pension fund. No employee of Fulton County, other than policemen and firemen, shall participate in the public safety employees' pension fund. No elected official of Fulton County shall be entitled to participate in the public safety employees' pension fund. Any person eligible to participate in the public safety employees' pension fund shall affirmatively elect to so participate within 60 days of his employment, or within 60 days after December 14, 1977, whichever date shall be later. Whenever any person who has been a member of any other pension fund maintained by Fulton County shall become a member of the public safety employees' pension fund all amounts contributed by that person to the other pension fund, together with employer matching funds, shall be transferred to the public safety employees' pension fund. Any obligations undertaken by that person to pay for prior service shall be payable to the public safety employees' pension fund. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-2) 
Sec. 154-403. - Age of retirement; reduced benefits for early retirement. 
All members who shall retire as a matter of right must attain the age of 55 years and shall have served 25 years before being eligible to retire; provided, however, that any member who has served 25 years may elect to retire on a reduced pension, the reduction to be 1/12 of three percent per month the member lacks being 55 years of age; provided, however, that the provisions of this section as to age limit shall not apply to any person claiming a pension by reason of total and permanent disability. When that member shall retire as a matter of right, he shall be paid a monthly pension equal to two percent of his monthly (base and service) earnings, multiplied by his years of creditable service. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this division, when any employee shall retire under the provisions of this division "years of creditable service" used for the computation of pension benefits shall include all unused sick leave which shall be to the credit of such individual, not exceeding a total of 90 days. Monthly earnings shall be the average of the highest 36 months base and service salary during the term of employment. Partial years of service shall be used in computation of benefits unless a person is retired by reason of age. No pension awarded under this division shall exceed 75 percent of monthly earnings as defined herein. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-3) 
Sec. 154-404. - Disability benefits. 
Partial pensions and pensions for total and permanent disability shall be computed by the same formula as is used for computing service pensions in section 154-403 above; provided, further, that disability incurred in the line of duty shall be computed by the same formula as used for computing service pensions in section 154-403 above, or in monthly pension equal to the amount the member would have been eligible to receive with 35 years' service with average monthly earnings being not less than the salary being paid a six-year policeman or fireman, or the actual amount which the member would have received had he retired, whichever shall be greater. No person shall be entitled to a partial pension for disability not in the line of duty unless he or she shall have at least five years of creditable service. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-4) 
Sec. 154-405. - Benefits to beneficiaries. 
Pensions for spouses as beneficiaries designated under the terms of this division shall be three-quarters of the amount the pensioner was receiving at the time of death on service pensions, total and permanent disability pensions not in line of duty, and death not in line of duty prior to eligibility for retirement, and three-quarters on disability or death incurred in the line of duty with the police or fire department of the amount the pensioner was receiving or would have received had he or she exercised his or her right to retire for and during her widowhood, or his widowerhood, and his or her life, and, provided, further, that the pension benefits for spouses shall be given to the minor child or children (natural or legally adopted) upon the prior deaths or remarriage of the spouse until the youngest child shall have become 18 years of age; provided, further, that if the beneficiary of pensioner receiving service pension benefits (other than the minor child or children) is more than five years younger than the pensioner, there shall be deducted from the pension 1/12 of two percent per month for each month that he or she is more than five years younger than the pensioner; provided, however, that the reduction of 1/12 of two percent per month shall not apply if the beneficiary is 55 years or more of age at the time he or she becomes eligible for benefits. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-5) 
Sec. 154-406. - Designation of beneficiary. 
Any member, male or female, may designate any time his spouse or child, or children, under the age of 18 years, as beneficiary of his pension benefits, the amount of such benefits being hereinbefore specified, provided that the additional contributions for beneficiaries required by this division are made for the period of time that a member has a beneficiary. When a member shall fail to designate a beneficiary for any period of time that he was able to do so, he shall in the event that he shall later designate a beneficiary, pay such sum as he would have paid had he designated a beneficiary originally, together with six percent interest. Such sum shall be payable in such installments bearing such interest as may be determined by the board of trustees. Designation of a beneficiary shall be compulsory as to each member of the fund having a spouse or child, or children, under the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-6) 
Sec. 154-407. - Death while in active service. 
Whenever any member participating in the provisions of this division shall die while in active service and having not less than ten years of active service prior to his or her death, his widow, or her widower, provided he or she has been designated as beneficiary and has been married to him or her for at least one year prior to his or her death, shall be entitled to receive a pension during his or her life until his or her remarriage representing three-quarters of the amount that the member of the pension fund would have been entitled to receive had he or she not died but had become as of the date of his or her death totally and permanently disabled within the provisions of this division from accident, injuries, or illness outside of official duties and not from his or her own indiscretion. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-7) 
Sec. 154-408. - Death in line of duty. 
When any member of the pension fund created by this division shall die as the result of injuries incurred in the line of duty, the compensation to which he or she would have otherwise been entitled from Fulton County shall be continued for one year and paid from pension funds to his spouse or minor children (natural or legally adopted) if no spouse. Any compensation received by the member or his beneficiary from Fulton County due to the injury, shall be deducted from the one year's compensation herein provided for. At the expiration of the one-year period referred to above, the pension benefits for the beneficiaries shall be computed by the same formula as set forth in section 154-403. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-8) 
Sec. 154-409. - Cost of living adjustment. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Adjusted pensioner index means the pensioner base index adjusted, on a cumulative basis, for all percentage adjustments made in benefits prior to the current annual adjustment date. The adjusted pensioner index and the pensioner base index shall be applicable to any beneficiary becoming entitled to the benefits under this division in the same manner as they would have been applicable to the pensioner had such pensioner continued in life. 
Annual adjustment date means January 1 of each year. 
Current average cost-of-living index means the average of the monthly Consumer Price Index for the 12-month period from November 1 through October 31, prior to the annual adjustment date, as determined by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor for all items and major groups, United States city average. 
Pensioner base index means the average of the Consumer Price Index for the 12-month period ending two months prior to the date of retirement for any participant who retires under the provisions of this division. In the event the base year used in computing the monthly Consumer Price Index should be changed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the board of trustees shall, with the advice of an independent actuary, adjust the pensioner base index of each retired pensioner and of each pensioner or beneficiary, with benefit payments commencing during the first year in which such change was made, so as to effect the original intent of this section in an equitable manner. 
(b)  Adjustment. The board of trustees shall ascertain the current average cost-of-living index as of January 1 each year, and the benefits being paid under this division shall be adjusted as of the annual adjustment date as follows: 
(1)  If the current average cost-of-living index is more than 100 percent of the adjusted pensioner index, the benefits shall be increased by a percentage equal to the difference between the 100 percent and the percentage representing the current average cost-of-living index divided by such person's adjusted pensioner index. 
(2)  If the current average cost-of-living index is less than 100 percent of the adjusted pensioner index, such person's basic benefits shall be reduced by a percentage equal to the difference between 100 percent and the percentage representing the current average cost-of-living index divided by his adjusted pensioner index. 
(c)  Exception. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, no increase or decrease in the amount of the monthly retirement benefit due to changes in the current average cost-of-living index, effective at any annual adjustment date, shall be in excess of three percent of the amount of the monthly retirement benefit payable immediately prior to such date. Neither shall the provisions of this section be applied so as to reduce the amount of the benefits of a pensioner or beneficiary of an amount less than that to which such pensioner or beneficiary would be entitled to receive under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-9) 
Sec. 154-410. - Determination of death or disability. 
The board of trustees shall have the authority to determine the permanent and total disability of any member of the fund and to determine whether such disability or death has occurred in the line of duty. The board of trustees may adopt appropriate regulations to carry out the purposes of this section. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-10) 
Sec. 154-411. - Refunds of contributions. 
Any member of the pension fund created by this division who leaves the employ of Fulton County prior to receiving any benefits under this division, shall have refunded to him an amount equal to the amount which he has paid into the fund. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-11) 
Sec. 154-412. - Rights of pensioners. 
The rights herein created shall not be construed as rights under a contract, but shall be subject to future change or revision, and no member or beneficiary herein provided for shall be deemed to have any vested right to any annuities or benefits provided herein; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall operate to deprive any member of the fund from the right to postpone the drawing of benefits in the same manner as provided by law for members of the general employees' pension fund. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-12) 
Sec. 154-413. - Attachment of benefits. 
None of the funds herein mentioned shall be subject to the process of garnishment, attachment, or other legal process, nor shall any of the funds to be paid or disbursed under the provisions of this division be assignable, but shall be paid in cash to the beneficiary thereto if requested by him or her. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-13) 
Sec. 154-414. - Deductions from employees. 
There shall be deducted from the total salary of any member of the pension fund the sum of seven percent of his total salary in the event he does not provide for payment of a pension to a beneficiary, as provided for by this division, or the sum of eight percent of his total salary in the event that he does provide for the continuation of the pension to his beneficiary. There shall also be paid a matching amount from the general funds of Fulton County. Notwithstanding any agreement of any member to the contrary, the amounts authorized by this section shall be the maximum amount required from any member for any creditable service unless the member shall be liable to pay either interest or the employer's matching share. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-14) 
Sec. 154-415. - Appropriations to maintain fund. 
Should the fund at any time be insufficient to meet and pay the pensions authorized under this division, Fulton County shall appropriate from current funds sufficient amount to make up the difference. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-15) 
Sec. 154-416. - Prior service with City of Atlanta; effect. 
No person participating in the pension fund created by this division claiming credit for prior service for time spent with the City of Atlanta shall be entitled to retire as a matter of right on a standard service pension until he or she shall have actually been in the employ of Fulton County for a period of five years. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-16) 
Sec. 154-417. - General employees' pension fund; applicability. 
Except where in express conflict with the provisions of this division, the provisions of the law creating the employees' pension fund (1939 Ga. Laws, page 571, as amended) are hereby incorporated herein by reference. It is the intent of this section to provide that the general employees' pension fund and the public safety employees' pension fund shall (as nearly as practicable) be operated under the same provisions of law and rules and regulations. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-17) 
Sec. 154-418. - Previous service with other employers. 
Any participant in the pension fund established by this division who was employed by the State of Georgia or was a member of the General Assembly of Georgia or was employed by a municipality located, in whole or in part, in Fulton County, or who was employed by the Fulton County Board of Education or the Atlanta-Fulton County Recreation Authority, or who was an active member of the United States armed forces may claim credit for such service rendered prior to his employment with Fulton County, a year of such service counting for purposes of this resolution the year of service in Fulton County upon the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  No credit shall be given for part-time or temporary service. 
(2)  When such participant has served five years with Fulton County, he shall be eligible to receive credit for any periods of prior service authorized under this section, four years for military service, and not to exceed ten years when combined with any other prior service, other than military, claimed hereunder. 
(3)  Application must be made for prior service credit within six months after first becoming eligible for claiming such service. Any participant who does not claim prior service under this section within said period of six months shall pay into the pension fund interest on the total amount due the fund from six months following the date such person first became eligible to claim such service. Interest charged shall be the average rate of return determined by the board of trustees. 
(4)  To obtain prior service credit, such participant shall pay into the pension fund in addition to all of the sums required by this division, eight percent of the current salary of such participant times the period of time claimed (which shall include payment for beneficiary coverage). The provisions of this subsection (4) shall be applicable only to those individuals employed or reemployed following June 21, 1989. 
(5)  No years of credit allowed under this section shall be used to obtain pension benefits in any other pension system supported, in whole or in part, with public funds. 
(6)  It shall be the responsibility of the officer or employee making application for such credit to furnish to the board of trustees proof for the years of service and the monthly rate of compensation in such manner as the board may by rule prescribe. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-18; Ord. of 6-21-89, § 1) 
Sec. 154-419. - Payment in installments. 
Any payments due to the pension fund created by this division and the terms of this section of this division, may be paid in equal monthly installments not to exceed 60. Such installments shall bear interest at a rate equal to the average return on pension fund investments for the fiscal year preceding the date in which the election to pay in installments is made. Such average rate of return shall be determined annually by the board of trustees of the pension board created hereby. The amounts shall be deducted from any compensation due the participant or from pension payments. The board of trustees shall require an assignment of a life insurance policy in an amount at least equal to the amount due to the pension fund. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-19) 
Sec. 154-420. - Election to participate. 
In the event that any individual who was a member of this fund on February 1, 1982, shall fail to file an election to participate in the amendments to this division adopted by the Fulton County Board of Commissioners on February 3, 1982, by reason of the death or disability of such individuals, an election to participate in said amendment may be filed on behalf of such participant by the individual who is, or would be, the beneficiary of such individual under the terms of this division. Such election shall be effective, provided that it shall be filed with the secretary of the pension fund on or before August 1, 1982, and shall be accompanied with an agreement to make the increased contributions occasioned by said amendment adopted on February 3, 1982. Upon the filing of such election, said individual or his beneficiary shall be entitled to all of the benefits of the aforementioned amendment. 
(Code 1983, § 24-4-20) 
Secs. 154-421—154-460. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PREJUDICIAL ACTS POLICY AND PROCEDURE 

Sec. 154-461. - Purpose of article. 
This article is designed to assist employees in identifying acts motivated by prejudicial and biased behavior toward an individual because of race, color, religion, citizenship, national origin, gender, age, disability, ethnic background or sexual orientation. 
(100-38, 7-10-96) 
Sec. 154-462. - County government policy towards prejudicial acts. 
It is the policy of Fulton County government to safeguard the rights of all employees as set forth by federal and state laws and Fulton County Personnel Regulations irrespective of their race, color, religion, ethnic background, citizenship, national origin, gender, age, disability and sexual orientation. Any acts or threats of violence, property, damage, harassment, intimidation or other acts designed to infringe upon these rights are viewed very seriously by Fulton County and will be given high priority. Fulton County government will use every necessary resource rapidly and decisively to identify the perpetrators and take immediate steps to prevent further acts. 
(100-38, 7-10-96) 
Sec. 154-463. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Color means a person being of one of the following skin colors: black, brown, red, yellow or white. 
Ethnic group means a group of persons of the same race or national origin who share common or similar traits, languages, customs and traditions including but not limited to black, white, Asian, Arab, Hispanic, Native American or other racial/ethnic/national groups. 
Prejudice means a negative or hostile attitude toward a person or group formed without just or sufficient knowledge and based on negative stereotypes. 
Prejudicial acts means any action designed to frighten, harm, injure, intimidate or harass an individual, in whole or in part, because of a bias motivation against the actual or perceived race, color, religion, gender, age, disability, ethnic background or sexual orientation of the victim. 
Prejudicial incident means any act, whether consisting of conduct, speech or expression, to which prejudicial motive is evident as a contributing factor, without regard for whether the act constitutes mistreatment or abuse of employees, coworkers or citizens. 
Prejudicial motive means hatred, hostility or negative attitudes toward, or prejudice against, any group or individual on account of citizenship, race, religion, ethnicity/national origin, gender, age, disability or sexual orientation which is a contributing factor, in whole or in part, in the commission of a bias act. A bias motive can be inferred from the presence of one or more bias indicators. A bias motive may also be inferred from an intent to interfere with, disrupt or deprive another person of his or her civil or constitutional rights by threats, intimidation, harassment or coercion. The specific forms of prejudicial acts covered by the harassment policy. 
Race means a group of persons who possess common physical characteristics (e.g., color of skin, eyes and/or hair, facial features, etc.) ethically transmitted by descent and heredity that distinguish them as a distinct division of humankind (e.g., Asians, blacks, whites, etc.). 
Religious group means any group of persons who share the same religious beliefs regarding the origin and purpose of the universe and the existence or nonexistence of a supreme being, including but not limited to Catholics, Jews, Protestants, Islamic, Moslem, other religions and atheists. 
Sexual orientation means a sexual attraction toward, and responsiveness to, members of one's own sex or members of the opposite sex, e.g., gays, lesbians, heterosexuals, etc. 
(100-38, 7-10-96) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 101-2. 
Sec. 154-464. - Examples of prejudicial acts. 
The following criteria and examples can assist in determining whether a particular behavior should be classified as a prejudicial act. These criteria are not all-inclusive, and each case must be examined on its own facts and circumstances. Common sense judgment should also be applied in making the determination whether an action should be classified as a prejudicial act. 
(1)  Comments, insults, derogatory language, ethnic jokes, teasing, written statements, gestures. Prejudicial and bias-related comments, written statements or gestures. 
(2)  Drawings, markings, symbols and graffiti. 
a.  Prejudicial-related drawings, markings, symbols or graffiti left at the scene of the incident, i.e., burning crosses, nooses, white hoods, Nazi swastikas, literature or pictures depicting the human anatomy. 
b.  Prejudicial-indicators need not establish that the predominant purpose of an employee's actions was motivated by prejudice, hatred or bias. It is sufficient for classification of an incident as a bias act that an individual was acting out of prejudice, hatred or bias, together with other motives, or that a bias motive was a contributing factor, in whole or in part, in the commission of said act. 
c.  Racial, religious, ethnic/national origin, gender, age, disability or sexual orientation of the individual allegedly committing the act differs from that of the individual to whom the acts were directed. 
d.  The individual to whom the act was directed was engaged in activities promoting the targeted group. 
e.  Incident coincided with a holiday or date of particular significance to the targeted group. 
f.  Although not a member of the targeted group, the employee is a member of an advocacy group that supports the targeted group, or the employee was in the company of a member of the targeted group. 
(3)  Previous existence of prejudicial acts crime/incidents. 
a.  Complainant is an employee at a location where previous bias crimes had been committed against members of the targeted group. 
b.  Several incidents occurred in the same area, and the employee is a member of the targeted group. 
c.  Employee has received previous harassing mail or phone calls or has been the victim of verbal abuse based on his or her affiliation with a targeted group. 
(4)  Employee/witness perception. The employee or witnesses perceive that the incident was motivated by bias and prejudice. 
(5)  Motive of offender. 
a.  Individual allegedly committing the act was previously involved in a similar incident or is a member of, or associates with members of, an organized hate group. 
b.  The employee was in the company of, or married to, a member of a targeted group. 
c.  The employee was perceived by the offender as violating or breaking from traditional conventions or working in nontraditional employment. 
(100-38, 7-10-96) 
Sec. 154-465. - Supervisor's responsibilities. 
Upon receiving a complaint, the supervisor will confer the initial complainant and take measures to ensure that all necessary preliminary actions have been taken and inform management (i.e., department head or deputy director) of the prejudicial act. The supervisor will request the assistance of appropriate personnel necessary to provide immediate assistance to the complainant, such as: 
(1)  Expressing official position that said actions violate county policy and that measures will be taken to apprehend the perpetrators. 
(2)  Allow the employee a period in which to ventilate his or her immediate concerns and express their feelings. 
(3)  Conduct a standard preliminary investigation to include preliminary interviews of the employee and any witnesses to the incident. Ensure that all relevant facts are documented regarding an incident. 
(4)  Notifying other appropriate personnel in the chain of command and the contract compliance and EEO department depending on the nature and seriousness of the offense, and its potential inflammatory and related impact on the department and Fulton County. 
(100-38, 7-10-96) 
Sec. 154-466. - Investigating complaints of prejudicial acts. 
(a)  The department of contract compliance and equal employment opportunity (EEO) will have responsibility for investigating complaints, prejudicial acts or incidents. Such complaints will have priority and will be handled in a timely manner. 
(b)  Any employee who believes that he or she has been subjected to a prejudicial act or incident should file a written complaint with the department of contract compliance and EEO. This complaint should include a description of the behavior complained of, the date(s) of the behavior, the identity of the person committing the alleged prejudicial acts, a brief description of the circumstances and facts surrounding the events of prejudicial act and the name of any person who may have knowledge of facts or circumstances surrounding the complaint. 
(c)  After receiving the complaint, the department of contract compliance and EEO will review the complaint and discuss the allegations with the complainant. Thereafter, the department of contract compliance and EEO will confer privately with the person alleged to have committed the prejudicial act. The department of contract compliance and EEO will invite and require the alleged violator or offender, and will also interview all supervisory personnel, to respond to the complaint in writing. The department of contract compliance and EEO will investigate the facts contained in the complaint, including reviewing all documentary information and interviewing persons who may have knowledge of the complaint, and consulting with legal counsel, if necessary. The investigation will be confidential and all documents received in connection therewith will be considered confidential and privileged to the extent allowed by law. The department of contract compliance and EEO will make a recommendation to the county manager and the department head, regarding whether the complainant has been a victim of a prejudicial act, and any corrective action recommendations. The department of contract compliance and EEO will also advise the complainant of the results of the investigation, as well as other alternatives for redress. 
(d)  All complaints shall be filed as soon as possible but no later than 30 days after the occurrence of the alleged prejudicial act or incident. Nothing in this article shall be construed to require a complainant to file a written complaint with the department of contract compliance and EEO prior to or in lieu of seeking redress with other agencies or the courts. 
(100-38, 7-10-96) 
Sec. 154-467. - Disciplinary action. 
All disciplinary action for violation of this article shall be governed by the guidelines set forth in the Personnel Regulations of Fulton County. Appeals of disciplinary actions by permanent classified employees shall be made to the personnel board or to the grievance review committee in accordance with the provisions of the Personnel Regulations of Fulton County. Department heads and nonclassified employees may seek redress for any disciplinary action through the grievance review committee. Officials appointed by the Board of Commissioners of Fulton County may seek redress for any disciplinary action before the board. Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit any person from seeking redress with any federal or state agency, or the courts. 
(100-38, 7-10-96)

Chapter 158 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Ordinances pertaining to buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; ordinances pertaining to planning, ch. 58; planning system for mapping and surveying landmarks, § 102-3; resolutions pertaining to buildings and building regulations, ch. 106; resolutions pertaining to community development, ch. 118; subdivision regulations, app. A; zoning, app. B. 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt plans and exercise zoning powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 158-1. - Conflicts of interest in zoning matters and lobbyist disclosure. 
(a)  The Board of Commissioners of Fulton County hereby directs the county attorney to prepare a form to be sent to each member of the board of commissioners by the director of development services for each rezoning application which form shall include a clear description of each property to be presented for rezoning, the names of all individuals who have an ownership interest in the property, the names of all business entities which have an ownership in the property, and a space where each commissioner may indicate whether he/she has a property or financial interest in the property submitted for rezoning. 
(b)  The director of development services shall prepare a form, approved by the county attorney, which shall accompany each zoning application whereby the rezoning applicant, his/her attorney, or other person acting on the applicant's behalf or any opponent to a rezoning shall disclose any campaign contribution made to members of the board of commissioners in accordance with applicable law; and the director of development services shall further make available such forms at all public hearings on rezoning to members of the public who oppose such rezonings, and all such disclosure forms shall be placed on file with the clerk to the board of commissioners. 
(c)  Members of the public shall be advised, through public notice of rezoning and announcements at each public hearing on rezoning matters, of the applicable disclosure requirements. 
(d)  All persons appearing before the board of commissioners, who promote or oppose any application for rezoning, shall be required to provide to the clerk to the board of commissioners verification of registration as a lobbyist with the state ethics commission, in accordance with applicable law. 
(94-RC-598, 12-21-94) 
Cross reference— Zoning, app. B. 
State Law reference— Conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67-A-1 et seq. 
Sec. 158-2. - Representatives of homeowners' associations and neighborhood coalitions; authority to speak and act on behalf of organization. 
(a)  The board of commissioners hereby adopts as its policy that representatives of homeowners' associations and other neighborhood coalitions offering comments, opinions, or opposition to any proposed application for proposed rezoning on behalf of such association or coalition must present a written, notarized document evidencing their authority to speak on behalf of the association or coalition, and further that any written private agreement between such homeowners' association or neighborhood coalitions and the applicant shall be signed by the president or other officer of the association, and shall show on its face that the person so signing has the authority to make the representation and/or offer the private agreement on behalf of the association or coalition. 
(b)  Representatives of homeowners' associations and other neighborhood coalitions may leave on file in the office of the clerk to the commission and development services department such notarized statement required above in subsection (a) of this section, which statement shall be valid for purposes herein for the period for which such person is the designated authorized representative. 
(c)  The clerk to the commission shall prepare a form, approved by the county attorney, which may be used by a representative subject to this policy, which form shall be available in the office of the clerk to the commission, development services department, and other appropriate county offices. 
(d)  This policy shall apply to representatives appearing before the Fulton County Board of Commissioners, Fulton County Planning Commission, and Fulton County Board of Zoning Appeals. 
(94-RM-781, 12-7-94) 
Sec. 158-3. - Public hearings for public projects. 
The board of commissioners hereby establishes as its policy that prior to the acquisition of land or other initiative related to the construction of a public project in Fulton County, public hearings, including one public hearing before the board of commissioners, shall be conducted so as to receive public comment, concern and information pertaining to the impact of the proposed project on the surrounding community. The county manager is hereby directed to develop a written procedure to be presented to the board of commissioners within 30 days to implement this policy. 
Editor's note— While the above section is derived from a resolution of the board of commissioners, specific information as to adoption date was not available as of the publication date of this Code. 
Secs. 158-4—158-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEVELOPMENT ADVISORY COMMITTEE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Boards, commissions, etc., § 102-601 et seq. 

Sec. 158-36. - Creation. 
There is hereby created a Development Advisory Committee of Fulton County, Georgia, to serve at the pleasure of the Board of Commissioners of Fulton County and for such duration as said board may desire. The members and alternate members of said committee shall be selected by the organizations invited to participate. 
(95-0205, § a, 2-15-95) 
Sec. 158-37. - Purpose. 
The purpose of the development advisory committee shall be: 
(1)  To advise the board of commissioners and the departments of development services, inspections and zoning enforcement, and public works on issues and matters of concern with regard to land development activities and regulations. 
(2)  To advise the departments of development services, inspections and zoning enforcement, and public works in the development of recommendations concerning the interpretation and implementation of land development regulations. 
(3)  To review and propose changes to existing and proposed land development regulations and amendments and advise the above-referenced departments and the board of commissioners on their impact and effectiveness. 
(4)  To carry out such studies or investigations regarding the land development regulatory process or requirements as the board of commissioners may request from time to time. 
(5)  The development advisory committee shall keep informed of new and innovative techniques, materials, methodology, and designs which would create or encourage overall quality development in Fulton County. 
(6)  The development services department, inspections and zoning enforcement, public works department, and/or any other county department maintaining regulations pertaining to land development shall submit all regulations or amendments thereto to the development advisory committee for review and comment. It shall be the responsibility of the director of such department to provide written recommendations, including that of the development advisory committee, at a public hearing, where action by the board of commissioners is required to adopt or amend an ordinance. 
(95-0205, § b, 2-15-95) 
Sec. 158-38. - Membership. 
The development advisory committee shall be comprised of 17 representatives selected by the following organizations: 

 
(95-0205, § c, 2-15-95) 
Sec. 158-39. - Operations. 
The members of the development advisory committee will elect, from among the membership, such officers as it may desire and for such term as it may desire. It may adopt such bylaws or operating procedures as deemed desirable by the majority of the membership. Meetings shall be scheduled at least quarterly and more often as deemed appropriate by the majority of the membership and as dictated by the workload. Meetings of the development advisory committee shall be open to all parties. While the committee shall invite any person to participate or involve any person in its discussions and deliberations, all matters requiring formal decisions shall be decided only by a vote of the representatives of the member organizations or designated alternate representatives. 
(95-0205, § d, 2-15-95) 
Sec. 158-40. - Limitation on membership. 
No employee of the Fulton County government may be a member of the development advisory committee. 
(95-0205, § e, 2-15-95) 
Sec. 158-41. - Compensation/operational costs. 
The members of the development advisory committee shall serve without compensation or reimbursement of any kind. Administrative support for committee meetings shall be coordinated or provided by the development services department. Member appointments and operational costs, including clerical assistance related to the production of ordinances, meeting notes, notification of members, and reproduction of exhibits, but not including typing special studies, letters, memoranda, or the like being generated by the committee members, shall be borne by Fulton County. 
(95-0205, § f, 2-15-95) 
Secs. 158-42—158-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMPREHENSIVE STRATEGIC PLAN 

Sec. 158-76. - Generally. 
(a)  Intent. It is the intent of this section that the comprehensive strategic planning process shall afford residents of each of the planning areas the opportunity to customize their county facilities and services to reflect the goals of their communities and neighborhoods. The comprehensive strategic plan (CSP) shall identify needs based on community-generated goals and standards, an inventory of existing public facilities and services, and an assessment of future facility and service needs. 
(b)  Effect. Upon adoption, the CSP shall be an official policy guide, and, as a public record, its primary purpose shall be to inform the public and to assist the county management, county departments, and the planning commission and board of commissioners in the performance of their duties. 
(c)  Adoption and duration. The CSP may be adopted, added to, and changed from time to time, by a majority of the Fulton County Board of Commissioners. Such amendment or adoption shall be in accordance with the provisions of 1989 Ga. Laws (Act No. 634), pages 1317—1391 and the planning enabling resolution of the Board of Commissioners of Fulton County, Georgia, adopted March 20, 1974. 
(d)  Duties of director. As a participant in Fulton County's planning, programming, and budgeting system (PPBS), the department of planning and economic development's director shall cause to be developed a comprehensive strategic plan (CSP) for services and facilities that shall be submitted to the board of commissioners for a public hearing and approval, and updated from time to time. 
(e)  Components. The department, in preparing the CSP, shall assess demographics and forecast demographic changes as they relate to county services, facilities, goals, objectives, and policies, together with a six-year work program encompassing time and priority schedules, cost estimates for accomplishment of proposed projects, and identification of the entity responsible for implementation. The CSP shall include departmental strategic plans including all programs and services provided by the county within functional program areas, and these strategic plans shall be linked directly to operating and capital budgets. The CSP shall include current and proposed land use maps and maps to show existing and proposed streets, railroad and transit lines, airports, parks, playgrounds, forests, reservations, wetlands, open spaces, special districts, revitalization areas, preservation areas, redevelopment areas, locations of utilities, and other planning features. The land use plan map should take into account the community's preferences for general locations of land uses that are consistent with the goals, objectives, and policies developed in the plan and adopted planning standards. 
(94-RC-508, § 28-2-6, 10-19-94) 
Sec. 158-77. - Program analysis and evaluation. 
As part of Fulton County's planning, programming, and budgeting system (PPBS), the programs identified in the comprehensive strategic plan (CSP) for providing facilities and services shall be linked directly to the annual operating and capital budgets. The success of that link shall be monitored through the department's program analysis and evaluation division. The program analysis and evaluation division shall assess the efficiency and effectiveness of Fulton County's departmental and interdepartmental programs, and shall serve as an advocate for program implementation. The division shall assist the county's nine functional groups with their budget presentations and shall evaluate all requested program changes for continuity with the county's strategic goals. The division shall also assist departments in preparing their six-year strategic plans, validating program performance indicators, implementing a county-wide program performance reporting system, and coordinating and preparing the county's capital improvement program and annual capital budget. 
(94-RC-508, § 28-2-7, 10-19-94)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 162-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Res. No. 01-0957, adopted Aug. 15, 2001, repealed § 162-1 in its entirety. Formerly said section pertained to commission on road improvements as related to roads and bridges. See the Code Comparative Table.
